channel.title: Server Speed
channel.description:
Sometimes when I turn a server on it's normal, and other times when I run around I'll be running at almost twice the speed of what is normal.
Is this to do with the -Xmx in the batch files? Or the server cycle? Or something else?

item.title: Server Speed
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

Mendorphins:

bearing in mind it is all 317 graphics, so probably easier on my graphics card to render.

317 uses software rendering, the only thing your graphics card is involved in is transferring the rendered image to the screen: it does not draw any of the scene itself.

Read full topic

item.title: Server Speed
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

Well I was up to 50 - 60 FPS when I checked and that’s rather higher considering my laptop is slow. On RS I’d be lucky to get 6 FPS (and Jagex claim their streaming is more smoother on HD) - bearing in mind it is all 317 graphics, so probably easier on my graphics card to render.

I don’t suppose you can artificially make your FPS lower can you?

Read full topic

item.title: Server Speed
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

That sounds like your FPS (frames per second) is slow/modified. Not exactly sure though…

Read full topic

item.title: Server Speed
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

My character runs almost as twice as fast, as if someone has got the game on 1.5X fast forward. Sometimes servers have done the opposite and been running too slow, as if the run animation isn’t in sync with moving across the map.

Read full topic

item.title: Server Speed
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Mendorphins:

I guess is it is just a maximum amount of memory the runtime is allowed to take up. The question is would this effect me running around at twice the speed, if the server and client -Xmx’s are not the same.

Probably not.

What exactly do you mean running at twice the speed as normal? Like the client is, for example “walking” at twice the speed, or the chat messages disappear faster?

Read full topic

item.title: Server Speed
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

I guess is it is just a maximum amount of memory the runtime is allowed to take up. The question is would this effect me running around at twice the speed, if the server and client -Xmx’s are not the same.

Read full topic

item.title: Server Speed
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Mendorphins:

Well I have 512MB Ram and it’s set to -Xmx512m for both the server and client. I’ll half it for both. I knew it allocated memory but didn’t know exactly what effects that it caused apart from allocating the memory. xD

I think I may have worried it wrong. I don’t really use the -Xmx option, and the information I posted was just a summary of the sites I looked at. I don’t know if it allocates x bytes at start up, or if it expands as needed until it reaches x, and then throws an OOMException

Read full topic

item.title: Server Speed
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

Well I have 512MB Ram and it’s set to -Xmx512m for both the server and client. I’ll half it for both. I knew it allocated memory but didn’t know exactly what effects that it caused apart from allocating the memory. xD

Read full topic

item.title: Server Speed
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Fridder, post:4, topic:391344”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=487289.msg3571569#msg3571569 date=1303083051]

Sometimes when I turn a server on it’s normal, and other times when I run around I’ll be running at almost twice the speed of what is normal.

Is this to do with the -Xmx in the batch files? Or the server cycle? Or something else?

-Xmx sets the max heap size for the application.
[/quote]

What does that mean? The higher the better?[/quote]

No. What it does is pre-allocate the specified amount of RAM at startup, and that RAM belongs to the java process until it exits. So for example if you do “-Xmx1024” it allocates about 1 GB to the java process. It affects the speed of the application very little. I mean, there might be some small run-time optimizations (pointers relative to the start of the segment, instead of the current active memory)

Read full topic
